We returned to Tally this weekend with our Nole grads to spend time at Proof!  We enjoyed great beer as always and chilled in the back patio.  What an awesome place to hang out and reminisce.  Can't recommend Proof enough!
Enjoyed a few colds ones while visiting FSU with my son.  Great selection of beers and food truck had some solid options.  Great patio seating along with friendly staff!  Worth checking out!

This is Proof's production brewery location inside the Railroad Art Park.  Inside they have a bar area with about 20+ taps serving their beers and guest brews.  You can see the brewery floor through the windows in the bar. The highlight of this location is the outdoor space with tables, benches, awnings and games like cornhole. I think their pub over on Tennessee street can sometimes be an overdose on "hip" so this location is a nice. laid-back change of pace. You can buy growlers and also Crowlers (the new aluminum can growlers) to go. Kids and pets are welcome depending on the crowd level and events planned. They don't have food but they do have food trucks that show up. Closed Mo-Tu, We-Fr: 4pm-midnight, Sa: 3pm- midnight, Su: noon-6pm.

We found proof by Google search and figured we would give it a try.  Cool place where the bartenders know their beer and are friendly and helpful. They have an area to enjoy your beer inside or outside. It was very cool out so they had heaters on the patio.  There is a large backyard area where people can play some games. ( way too cold for us!). The ambiance at this place is perfect.  Great for college kids or parents to hang out and enjoy a few beers.

This is Proof's production brewery location inside the Railroad Art Park.  Inside they have a bar area with about 20+ taps serving their beers and guest brews.  You can see the brewery floor through the windows in the bar. The highlight of this location is the outdoor space with tables, benches, awnings and games like cornhole. I think their pub over on Tennessee street can sometimes be an overdose on "hip" so this location is a nice. laid-back change of pace. You can buy growlers and also Crowlers (the new aluminum can growlers) to go. Kids and pets are welcome depending on the crowd level and events planned. They don't have food but they do have food trucks that show up. Closed Mo-Tu, We-Fr: 4pm-midnight, Sa: 3pm- midnight, Su: noon-6pm.

A group of us arrived at Proof and one of our party asked if they had any non-alcoholic beer.  The server said “we wouldn’t do that to beer!” The server meant to be funny but it was not.  Anyone who chooses not to drink alcohol should be treated with respect, hospitality, and kindness.  Definitely not cool.  We won’t be back.

This is a large establishment with spacious accommodations for several diverse groups at the same time. There were 4 different groups when ours was celebrating. There was no confusion and each had its own separate area to congregate 
We were in a private venue with our own Kareoke setup, private catering and bar. The staff was professional, friendly and efficient. The food was GREAT. It included a variety of wings, chips, sliders, chicken and more tasty bites.

Very nice and lively brewery.  Outstanding selection...try the nitro mango!  Friendly and attentive staff...fun place for a Friday night.  The food selections outstanding looked popular.  Very clean restrooms as well

We held my milestone birthday party in the private room at Proof and had an awesome time.  Beautiful private room with its own bar, along with outside area.  The cool November weather was great and allowed us to utilize both the outside and inside areas comfortably for our 40+ guests.  Beautifully decorated and complete with tables and chairs, along with outside furniture, heaters and cornhole games, the private room space is great for any event.  And they offer a private tour of the brewery for your guests.  You can select up to 8 beers, along with white and red sangria to have on tap.  Proof can also set up a full bar if you want that for your party.    Proof partners with Proper to offer catering for your event.  Proper has lots of food options to choose from including appetizers and full meals.  But best of all is the wonderful craft beers!

This brewery is a bit off the beaten path, but they have fantastic beer that can be found at any bar in town. They are also working on going nation wide and it would not surprise me at all if they are one of the most well known craft beer suppliers in the southeast in the next few years. There beer is really good. They have fantastic live music too. They had a bluegrass band last time I was there that I absolutely loved. If you go to Tallahassee, then you have to go to proof!

name: Apalachicola National Forest
reviews: Our drive through this national forest was wonderful.  Such tall trees was still vibrant green in late November.

Very nice setting in a long leaf pine and palmetto forest with other trees mixed in as well.  The campground is not very big (about 11 or so sites and only 4 or 5 have electricity and water) and the sites are relatively private.  Some sites have a view of the lake.   Bathrooms have showers, but the water is pretty hot and the showers need better placement of the hooks to avoid getting everything wet.  No shelves to place your clothes etc.  Toilet (one only) and shower (one only) are separate.   There is a set of shower/toilet for men and a separate one for women.
Very quiet and many birds singing early in the morning.   There is a gate that is locked at 8 pm but if you are camping you get a code to come in after hours.   Half price if you have a National park senior pass (you can get a senior pass for life for $10 when you turn 62 if you are a US citizen).   No cell phone or internet access in the campground.  Internet access was possible for me just outside the park.   The water is good (no strong flavors).  No restaurants or stores nearby so it is best to bring your food or eat before you get here.

Nice trail around the lake, great for an early morning or late afternoon walk. 
I camped for 3 nights here and enjoyed it in spite of the tiny no-see-ums (sandflies) that are active and sunrise and sunset.  For people with allergies the bites can be long lasting and very itchy (best to use insect repellent). 

I would return to this campground in the beautiful Apalachicola National Forest. 

Note:  The campground is supposed to be open year round if they have a campground host, other wise it is only open for day use.  It is $3 per person for day use.  There is a small fenced in beach and picnic areas, which can be popular with locals.  Reservations for camping can be made online.

Disclaimer: Much of this forest is true wilderness. Cell phones typically do not work, roads can be hard to follow, are not always well marked and can go from wide and firm to narrow and muddy without notice. You will not have access to any drinking water or bathrooms. Taking a wrong turn can take you 30 miles away from anything without a good chance to turn around. Even if you do get to a paved highway, you still may not be close to civilization. I always fill up on gas, bring food and water and have a map. I also only go with 4 wheel drive. This disclaimer is for the interior of the forrrest, there are trails acessible from the highways(Mainly Highways 98, 319, 65, 267 and 329) that do not require 4 wheel drive. Now thats out of the way.

This place is awesome, you can pick it up practically in town and follow it all the way to the coast. Countless lakes and streams. Some of the lakes are clear with sand bottoms and great for swimming, but watch for gators. There are unnamed creeks to fish and paddle, although many of the creeks can only be paddle a mile or 2. The creeks off the southern section of highway 65 offer some extensive paddling options but can be tricky so bring a map and watch tides. The Florida trail runs through it and there are several other singletrack hiking trails. Be careful during deer, hog and turkey season as hunting is huge here. You could spend 10 years exploring this place. Be careful, and enjoy
Our drive through this national forest was wonderful.  Such tall trees was still vibrant green in late November.
I just love driving around and seeing the natural beauty of the park and forest areas. Great for a Sunday afternoon drive.

After reading reviews and planning a driving trip through the national forest we were disappointed with our trip. We found no direction signs. There were no forest maps and few road signs to show what features were where. 
We traveled over 100 miles and saw no lakes, no wildlife, no campsites, no picnic areas, no parking pull off spots and nothing to entice us to ever return!
We lover our trip along the gulf coast into Apalachicola city but this was a sad disappointment.

I liked the fact that I saw wildlife. I saw a big beautiful Deer. Several Turtles,a flying squirrel. Several Turkey vultures. Just Beautiful no matter which way you looked. This the only national forest located in the Florida Panhandle. Its large with  632,890 acres. Camping is offered but Hotels are also available in nearby towns.

This forest butts up against the SW side of the City of Tallahassee. The area is well managed and that includes a very capable Prescribed Fire Program.  The forest is composted of flat woods, wetlands, pocosin, and a network of roads to help you get around.  Hunting is allowed on this forest with the proper permits.  There are many activities offered by the USFS as well as both other public and private groups.

name: Challenger Learning Center of Tallahassee
reviews: Always has fantastic nature films but also a great place to see the latest blockbuster.  Great sound and a beautiful screen.  Aqua-man was epic!

The 3D or non 3D movie experience is awesome! Great location downtown with restaurants across from the center and FSU nearby. Kids will love the interactive experience and astronaut food for purchase. It's a cool place for sure.

We spent some solid time here learning about the planets in the Center's Surround-Sound theatre.  Truly Amazing.  The guides in the Center taught us so much about NASA and the planets.  Things we didn't know--and the theater is really spectacular.
I want to visit here again. The Challenger Learning Center is not just for kids. I-Max theater is fantatic. See some of your favorite music movies there. Great sound and visual experience.

I think most of the good reviews here are for the IMAX, which I'm sure is a lovely experience, but the science side of things is lacking here. We have 3 small children and I expected this to be a kind of "exploreum" place. There are a couple of space suits in the lobby as well as some tinker toys and a giant Operation game (with broken buzzer) and beyond that- nada. I just wish we would have known exactly what it was (wasn't) before we came.
0 stars for hands-on science learning
3 stars for the fun planetarium show :)

Have been to 2 movies recently at imax at Challenger Learning Center. Lots of fun at a good price. They show 3D movies with surround sound. Movies for all ages. Discounts for children, students and seniors.
I like visiting here - great for kids to learn, and a good family outing place.   Enjoyable.  Parking under Klemann Plaza and walk!  Elevators there if you need.
Went on a Sunday night. Five of us there.  Show enjoyable but not spectacular.  Sound ok but not fantastic.  Didn’t really take in what else is there aside from a few displays.

name: Redemptive Love Farm
reviews:
Our kindergarten class visited the farm today.  It was really nice and peaceful.  We especially enjoyed the hands on experience.  We were really impressed with the young people who were most courteous.
Thank you!

Took my granddaughters here because they were offering a Unicorn photoshoot. This place is awesome and inspiring. It is run by a family. One of their children gave us a tour and introduced us to all of the animals. They are an animal rescue. Check out their website to learn more about what they do. We loved it and can't wait to go back.

we've been to this farm many times and always look forward to it! pony rides, an interactive petting zoo and animal feed for $1 (bring cash).  arrive early for best parking and to beat the summer heat.  the owners are wonderfully kind and genuine 👌🏼

I always look forward to activities that involve animals and the Redemptive Love Farm did not disappoint. There were many species of farm animals that were available to pet and/or hold. The baby piglets were my favorite as they would just sleep in your arms all day if you let them. The kids who live at the farm are the sweetest and are always willing to help you or teach you about the animals. I will definitely keep this hidden gem in my pocket and show it off to my visiting friends and family in the future.

name: Natural Bridge Battlefield Historic State Park
reviews: This state park is small and off the beaten path, but the local historical society and Civil War re-enactors contribute a LOT to keep this place up to high standards. Don't miss the battle re-enactment and living history events in Feb of each year. Nature lovers will appreciate the unique geological features found in the park and nearby.

This is the State Park that honors the Battle that kept Tallahassee (State Capitol of Florida) from being captured during the War Between the States (Civil War).  3 years ago the State added a large land purchase to it.  It's a beautiful site, Large UDC Monument and not much else, but important to take the little ones to and have their picture taken sitting on the Monument.  I have friends, brother & sister who have a photo of themselves sitting on it, almost 60 years ago, when it was new!  Incredible.

Learn more about the history of Florida and learn the story of Natural Bridge.  History buffs will like this site.  School age children studying Florida's history will also enjoy the nature trails and the hikes and the experience of learning something more about Florida.
A small park but worth the trip to see the monument. Combine it with a trip to st marks wildlife refuge and lighthouse.
Don't see going here for fun with the kids. But if history is important to you, then this place is special to see.

History buffs nice bit of American history, very small park w restrooms, short walk to river w whirlpool disappearing into a underground stream. Much of property was recently acquired. Nice memorial w great facts. $3 self pay fee

Historic marker and info about the Battle.  Would recommend visiting the St. Mark's National Wildlife Refuge first and foremost.  You can stop here on the way down or back from Tallahassee.  Probably don't want to make it your main focus.
This is a special park for so many locals and visitors, it's small, very peaceful and well kept by staff.

name: Tallahassee-St. Marks Historic Railroad State Trail
reviews: Having traveled hundreds, maybe thousands of miles, on Rails to Trails bike paths around the US, we have to say this is one of, if not THE, Best bike trail we have experienced. The scenery is spectacular, with magnificent live oak trees shading the trail and small farms along the way. The condition of the trail is excellent, straight, very well maintained, no debris, no bumps from tree roots. There is the added bonus of several concrete building rest rooms with benches. AND...get this...at each street crossing in which we encountered a vehicle, every single driver (total of 10) stopped to allow us to pass, waving us on. We have never encountered so many polite vehicle drivers while cycling. At the end of the trail there is a scenic park with picnic tables along the banks of the Wakulla River. There are informational signs along the way to tell you about the history of the trail and area. What a fantastic experience. We are already planning a return trip.

We visited this paved, well maintained bike trail early in the day.  Bicyclists, walkers, runners and skaters coexist easily on this trail.  Shaded, with plenty of restrooms along the way.  Follows an abandoned railroad track, so it is very flat.  We will definitely visit again.

What a great trail for biking. It's a very flat and wide paved trail. What was going to be a short ride turned into a 20 mile ride. Lots of stops along the way with benches water fountains and restrooms. Look forward to returning

Having traveled hundreds, maybe thousands of miles, on Rails to Trails bike paths around the US, we have to say this is one of, if not THE, Best bike trail we have experienced. The scenery is spectacular, with magnificent live oak trees shading the trail and small farms along the way. The condition of the trail is excellent, straight, very well maintained, no debris, no bumps from tree roots. There is the added bonus of several concrete building rest rooms with benches. AND...get this...at each street crossing in which we encountered a vehicle, every single driver (total of 10) stopped to allow us to pass, waving us on. We have never encountered so many polite vehicle drivers while cycling. At the end of the trail there is a scenic park with picnic tables along the banks of the Wakulla River. There are informational signs along the way to tell you about the history of the trail and area. What a fantastic experience. We are already planning a return trip.
If you are visiting the area, this is a cool stop by if you are visiting the area. Good eats nearby, motels could be more affordable.

We ride on every vacation. We read about this trail and decide to visit Tallahassee to ride this trail. The start point has a public bathroom with water. The trail is paved and smooth. There are few hills and curves. It is mostly covered with shade which worked out well because it was very hot. We rode out and back. If you are looking for a shady quiet place where people from all over ride with their families, this is a great spot to go.
Please let me know if you have questions and/or found this review helpful. Thanks.
*Additionally, check out my reviews on the Bradfordville Blues Club, Tallahassee Museum, and Tallahassee Antique Car Museum.

Nice flat trail, well maintained, mostly shaded, clean Porta potties along the trail, safe, 
We like to ride down and have lunch and then ride back

We use this trail on weekends, state parks have taken an old railroad right of way and made it into a hiking/biking trail.  Would highly recommend this to riding on the streets of tallahassee if you are an avid bike rider -- it is a LOT safer

name: Governor's Square mall
reviews: Its an ok mall. Address is kind of confusing because you can not see it from a short distance (down the hill) and there are a plenty of other stores around the area. Not your typical Floridian mall...

As long time Tallahassee residents we have enjoyed this mall and watched it grow since it opened decades ago. We've been in larger malls but none as well maintained at the Governors Square. 

We look forward each Christmas to their holiday decorations and Santa's visit. It's a very family friendly place with a extensive food court, a fantastic sit down Italian restaurant and a wildly popular national brand coffee shop.

Recent updates to the mall's interior has made it very modern and appealing. Many property's around the country have been plagued by crime and some actually closed due to a lack of customers; not the Governors Square Mall. You feel very safe on this property.  The parking lots are well lit and promote openness of natural surveillance and the entire property is routinely patrolled by highly visible private security. 

Many brand name stores have been here for years and appear to prosper. Rarely have I seen a vacant store front and if there is one, it's not vacant for long. 

With on-line shopping's rising popularity, we sincerely hope the Governors Square mall continues to thrive. Because it's much more than a shopping center. It's a social community gathering place that also happens to have places to shop and grab a bite to eat.

Even when Governor's Square Mall is not as big as many other Malls, you can find all kind of stores and the plus is that everything is in a reasonable price. Tallahassee is a city where most of students are, so, there why is cheap. 
They have a good food court... from salads to hamburguesa and pastries.

Its an ok mall. Address is kind of confusing because you can not see it from a short distance (down the hill) and there are a plenty of other stores around the area. Not your typical Floridian mall...

There are a lot of stores and a food court also. The people are very nice and will help you anytime. You can find just about anything you like too. My daughter loves to walk around in the mall and look at everything and so do I. It's beautiful place.

The anchor stores are ok. Dillard’s is the best of one. Macy’s is tired and old. The other 2 are Sears and Penny’s. That being said, it is just like the thousands of aging malls found around the nation. Nothing special, not great or terrible. We rarely spend more than 2 hours  there. Malls are for the young. Being in our 50s, we go for a purpose not to browse and hangout.
Wasin town for the weekend. Shopped at the mall on Saturday. Great selection of stores. Was limited in buying due to travel but did some damage. lol

Had a great time shopping and the food court had delicious dishes. Spend nearly everyday at the mall. Took my daughter to Tallahassee for school after Hurricane Irma. Now Governor's Square mall is my daughter favorite place to shop.

name: Lichgate on High Road
reviews: The old oak tree was really something to see.  The walkways, the gardens, the Tudor house, along with the outdoor classroom are in need of help.

Almost like an outdoor chapel in the middle of college apartments.
Thank Goodness it has been saved!
Beautiful old oak tree in a park like setting.Lovely place too goo meditate and just enjoy the nature trail and the cottage

I forget how I first heard about this mighty oak, but when visiting Tallahassee in April 2019 my husband and I made it a point to visit this tree....so glad we did. It took a little detective work and some GPS to find it exactly, small parking area and as you make your way to the oak tree in its clearing you can really feel the presence of this majestic oak. I pray that it will withstand any storms or hurricanes in its future as it has held tight over so many years. We live in Salem County NJ and just this summer our might Salem Oak 600 years old toppled down on a sunny June afternoon.....so visit this tree while you can. Namaste
This is such a lovely little haven. The great tree is just amazing. You can really feel the age of this little town here.
